comments.commentBody: What a silly comment.  Every year many private school kids take the test to attend Stuy or Hunter College H.S.   A small percentage get in and rest end up staying at their private school and tell everyone they just took the test for practice and that's why they were out scored by the public school kids.  Yes, somehow many public school kids still tested higher than the kids who had years of private education.  Obviously the same is true at the college level.  A public school education is certainly different than a private school education, but different doesn't always mean worse.

"But it does send a signal to your children when you deliberately opt to place them in a homogeneous setting despite there being minimal or no academic benefit. "

I teach at a state university, at a "research 1" in what is supposedly one of the best public systems in the country. I have also taught at private institutions, Ivies and selective liberal arts colleges, where significant numbers of undergrads come from private schools. In terms of preparation for college, there is simply no comparison. The kids from public schools are every bit as bright as the ones from the privates. But they are nowhere near as fluent writers, deep readers, or good critical thinkers. They have often never written a paper of over 5 pages, never been asked to do more than summarize what they read, never been asked to find a problem rather than solve a pre-determined one. They don't know how to use the resources of a research university or cultivate good working relationships with professors. And what's more, they often don't even know *what* they don't know, and are in for a real beating when they get out into the world. A mediocre student at a private high school, I am sorry to say, ends up with much better academic skills than a straight-A student from my state's public schools.

One small nit-pick.
I certainly agree with all you say here, but for one point: It wasn't the Church that castrated Abelard; it was Heloise's brothers.

David,
The story of Heloise and Abelard tells us a lot about how the twelfth century viewed the relations between the sexes, the primacy of the consecrated/educated life, and so on, but if you read the letters, you will see quite clearly that unless you want to complain about the pervasiveness of Catholicism in twelfth-century Europe, the Church really wasn't "invasive." Yes, Heloise's uncle went off the deep end when he thought Abelard was going to repudiate his marriage, and yes, St. Bernard took issue with Abelard's theology, but since everyone involved was operating within the same mental and moral universe, it's not as though Heloise and Abelard were victims of outside forces. Heloise's uncle and his thugs committed a heinous assault, but they were not agents of the Church at the time.

Maybe the rite started in 1614 but we an go back further to see the churches behavior when it comes to sexual behavior. The story of Heloise and Abelard should serve as a reminder just how invasive the church has been since the 1100s, and the punishment for having an affair.

The church knows people will have sex and it uses that to keep its flock under control. You have sinned and the only person who can help rid you of this guilt is Father The Venerable or such. Guilt is one of the most powerful psychological emotions and the church uses to keep you in their clutches. If you have sex for any reason other than procreation, you have sinned, and birth control pills allow you to do so.

John,

When I cook lobster for Elaine and myself, I always get a 3-4 pounder and split it. A 3 1/2 pound lobster has three times the meat of a 1 1/2 pounder. (The meat increases in proportion to the cube of the length while the shell goes with the square.) The small legs have some of the tastiest meat, but are not worth bothering with in a small lobster. Similarly, the body of a large lobster is like getting a free blue crab worth of meat. We always have plenty left over for lobster salad for lunch.

It is my experience that a four-pound lobster is every bit as tender and tasty as a 1 1/2 pounder. People tend to overcook lobsters, especially larger ones. My usual technique is to split the lobster alive and grill it. That way, you can cook it fairly quickly, the secret to tenderness. I also do them Chinese style, with black bean and pork. Quickly pre-deep fried and quickly stir fried, they are extremely succulent. And a three-pounder can serve 6 people.

We are lucky to get large lobsters at Chinese markets, with no cost premium for size. When they're on sale for $7/pound, I pounce.

I understand what you are saying, but can you deny, however regrettable and unfortunate it may be, that many black women WERE domestic servants in white families which variously appreciated or demeaned or patronised them? Did not Hattie MacDaniel herself say, when criticised, "I'd rather PLAY a maid than BE one? The real problem here lies for me not with the movie, which I quite liked, but with the novel, which might have resonated better for me had it been the work of an African-American woman, and not of a rather presumptuous white woman, who, despite her many alleged interviews with actual domestic workers of the era, still wrote with a detachment which made my skin crawl, especially in tose chapters narrated by African-American personae.

I agree wholeheartedly. Would I like to see more "realistic" progressive roles being played by African Americans....yes....but we were maids at one time.  We were all those things we strive not to be anymore.  But to negate those people is to negate our past. Most of "us" knew about the role of the Black nanny. She raised White children when their mothers didn't have time to, and the "help" had more sense, creativity, fortitude, and inner strength than their "bosses"  But many didn't know that story. There is more to it than even what we saw in this movie.  With all due respect, Tavis, as brilliant as he is...does not know everything about everything.  Bravo to Viola for standing her ground.  I love her even more for it.

These are good points and responses.  Not all whites are frightened, nor did I mean to imply that they were.  Nor do I have a problem with anyone choosing to spend their hard-earned money on protecting their children or sending them to the school that best fits their needs.  I only speak of some particular people I know personally whose fear of public schools and attendant stereotypes, such as the fear-inducing "metal detectors," has led to a leaving behind of children and whole communities within our community that will never have the chance to be protected and who need those of us who have the means to step up, even when we are uncomfortable.  I do not suggest sacrificing a child for principles but that we need to expand our work for public schools beyond suggesting others feel grateful that we pay our taxes and then can turn away from the children who do not have such choices (whether easy for the parents or very difficult as mentioned).

This is a very weird conversation. The roles that win actors Oscars are inevitably complicated, flawed characters, usually with lots of negative attributes. So of course that's true for black actors as well.

Nice characters with easy lives aren't particularly interesting and don't give an actor enough range to get nominated for any awards. So best actor Oscars nearly always go to actors, black and white, playing flawed characters overcoming major obstacles of all types.

Black actors who have won Oscars recently include Jamie Foxx (Ray), Forrest Whitaker (Last King of Scotland), and Denzel Washington (Training Day). What an incredibly varied set of characters they were playing! There is not a single stereotype that encompasses all of those characters except that they are flawed and complicated.

White actors who have won recently include Jeff Bridges (Crazy Heart), Colin Firth (The King's Speech), Daniel Day Lewis (There Will Be Blood), and Philip Seymour Hoffman (Capote). Again, a real variety of flawed, complicated characters.

I'm not saying that there isn't a lot of room for progress in opening up good roles to actors of all races (and both genders). But the mix of best actor wins in the last 10 years for black and white actors actually tells an incredibly positive story, especially compared to any previous decade.

Honestly, Viola Davis should win for her small, but far more compelling performance in "Extremely Loud..."
The problem with "the Help" is that it's really not that good of a film. Maybe fine for the Hallmark Channel (or an in-flight movie) but these roles have been played over and over again and NOBODY in the films delivers anything really new to art of acting.
Meanwhile, while "Extremely Loud..." is almost completely ruined by Tom Hanks and the very-annoying Thomas Horn, Max von Sydow and Viola Davis bring the work alive and give us performances that inspire. I guess she traded a "Best Actress" shot over a "Supporting Actress" win. Too bad!

I found "The Help" to be an eye-opening movie. Ms. Davis need make no apologies for portraying an honest, courageous woman in a dangerous era.

This particular comment brings to mind those who want American history texts rewritten to show the "benefits" of slavery.  No one could deny that there were Black Americans who defied the odds to become professionally and financially successful in an society that, at the same time, had lynchings. Even today, with a large middle class of Black Americans, one cannot deny the reality of those still struggling to overcome the effects of American racism. It's still more serious than just trying to get a taxi in NYC.  Furthermore, poor women of all colors are stil providing cheap but demanded servies, with new names like housecleaner and child care provider.  Their stories can be mundane, heroric, inspiring,heartbreaking, and even boring but sometimes they deserve to be told so that we remember where we came from, still are, and hope to be. And to keep the historical record intact.

“The black artist cannot live in a revisionist place”
I think that the revisionist history of "The Help" is a place where the Black artist goes to be stereotyped forever. That's the last place the Black artist should go, yet it's there and it has been gone to...
I think that Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer know that "The Help" is a pointless lie of a movie that preys upon negative stereotypes and entices the audience to believe the absolute untruth that African Americans in the 1950's or even prior were incapable of doing much more than being servants to white people. White Americans saved by Tuskegee Airmen over Europe, and SECOND-GENERATION and even THIRD-generation African American doctors, nurses, lawyers and other PROFESSIONALS whom with their families accumulated more wealth and more assets than those white families portrayed in this work of FICTION by the same decade it was set also know it is A POINTLESS LIE. I know. My GREAT GRANDFATHER was an African American DOCTOR, educated at Drexel's Medical University... and he PASSED AWAY AN OLD MAN 25 years BEFORE the setting of this movie.
Now, I FULLY understand the need to get your SAG chips in for retirement and health care benefits!!! Get your chips!!!

Yes, it is foolish to expect social realism from a hollywood film made about a commercial bestseller but give Viola Davis a break. She brought a fully dimensional, thoughtful and moral character to the screen. The character was doing the best that she could in the Jim Crow South. She deserves the Oscar.

Even a casual reading of history will tell you that Cleopatra was not black. She was a member of the Ptolemaic dynasty, a Macedonian Greek family. So it's quite reasonable to cast Angelina Jolie to play her.
It's not very helpful to claim racial bias where there is none.
GREAT movie, "Putney Swope"!!! Will never forget the Boorman Six advertisement!

This movie was based on a very popular novel. It was not created by the screenwriters but merely an interpretation of a novel that told the story of maids in Mississippi at a time when segregation was the standard in many parts of the country. Should white actresses have played these roles? If a movie is written about our first minority President and First Lady; should Asian actors be given the roles? The novel and the movie put a human face on all of these stereotypical roles from that time in Mississippi. There are movies where the roles are not defined as to race and any actor can be given the role. Sister Act was originally written with Bette Midler in mind and Whoopie Goldberg ended up being the actress. I don't disagree that minority actors should have more opportunities based on their talent and not their race but the script has to be one that can allow this. I still laugh at memorable scenes from Putney Swope. It poked fun at our racist society and was successful. I hope the best actor wins the Oscar; not the politically correct one.

If the only roles available are stereotypical, what is the Black actor supposed to do? It's not like filmmakers are able to envision people of color in roles written for white folks. Their mindsets are so closed off, they can't even see they are perpetuating these unfair stereotypes that appear to further racial discord. Or is that the point?

It is unfair to say that Ms. Davis plays the same part again and again. Her two Academy Award-nominated roles—in Doubt and then The Help—are two quite different roles: one snapshot of a mother consigned to her helpless station in society, the other a wide-angled look at an oppressed woman struggling to change the status quo for herself and others in her position.

That said, I do not believe that The Help is a study in the verisimilitude of blacks' lives in the '60s; it's a glossed-over portrait, at best. But that doesn't diminish Davis's feat. The raw emotion she injected into the part helped make up for the movie's lack of depth.

Ralph Fiennes received an Oscar for his portrayal of Amon Goeth. Moreover, Sandra Bullock won Best Actress for her portrayal of a suburban white mom in a film that—to many—contained undertones implying that blacks only achieved success with the help of whites. But Fiennes and Bullock were recognized for their acting and not admonished for the parts they played. Davis gave nuance to a flat movie. And, just as a white woman would be, she deserves to be lauded for her achievements.

If this is a defense of the film, I'd like to point you to an excellent quote from one of the links cited in the article.

"Portraying the most dangerous racists in 1960s Mississippi as a group of attractive, well dressed, society women, while ignoring the reign of terror perpetuated by the Ku Klux Klan and the White Citizens Council, limits racial injustice to individual acts of meanness.
We respect the stellar performances of the African American actresses in this film. Indeed, this statement is in no way a criticism of their talent. It is, however, an attempt to provide context for this popular rendition of black life in the Jim Crow South. In the end, The Help is not a story about the millions of hardworking and dignified black women who labored in white homes to support their families and communities. Rather, it is the coming-of-age story of a white protagonist, who uses myths about the lives of black women to make sense of her own. The Association of Black Women Historians finds it unacceptable for either this book or this film to strip black women’s lives of historical accuracy for the sake of entertainment."

I fear that you are indeed an Average American, who doesn't recognize a whitewash when it's writ large on the screen.
